title: Darts news: Peter Wright reacts to heartbreaking Michael van Gerwen loss
text:
Peter Wright was edged out 11-10 in the Champions League of Darts final (Picture: Getty Images)

Peter Wright suffered another devastating loss to Michael van Gerwen on Sunday night, missing three darts for the match before losing 11-10 in the Champions League of Darts final.

Snakebite turned in a superb performance in Leicester to go within a whisker of claiming the title and the £100,000 top prize, controlling the match and handing himself a perfect chance to win in the 18th leg.

Leading 10-7, Wright gave himself three clear darts at double 12 for the title, put the first two outside the wire before stepping back to compose himself, only to miss inside with the third.

The world number one bounced back to win four legs on the spin and win the Champions League for the first time, leaving Wright heartbroken.

MVG has now won eight major finals against Wright, with this one reminiscent of the razor thin victory in the 2017 Premier League final over the Scot.

On that dramatic night in London, Van Gerwen came back from 7-2 down to win the title and £250,000 after Wright missed six darts to get his hands on the trophy.

The world number seven was putting on a brave face after the gut-wrenching loss on Sunday night and is already looking forward to the European Championship next weekend.

‘I just want to thank all the sponsors, my sponsors and this amazing crowd for the whole weekend, they’ve all been amazing,’ Wright told the BBC.

‘I’ll get on with next weekend, that’s gone, that’s dusted, Michael won this one and I’ll get him back next time.’

When asked for a word on his opponent, Wright added: ‘Yeah, no, great. Well done Michael.’

Wright has now lost to MVG in finals at the World Championship, UK Open (twice), World Series Finals (twice), Premier League, Grand Slam, Grand Prix and the Champions League.

Van Gerwen, though, had little sympathy for his vanquished foe as he won the only major PDC event that he had never previously managed.

‘Peter put me under pressure and I made it really difficult for myself,’ said the world champion.

‘I shouldn’t have put myself in that position, Peter had a couple of clear darts to win the game. He missed, he was nervous because he looked around and I took great advantage of it.

‘I can’t complain, this was a phenomenal weekend for me, a high standard of darts, I didn’t have below a 100 average.’
